abstract: David K. P. Li, an aristocratic banker in Hong Kong, is expected to be questioned about a possible insider-trading case involving shares of Dow Jones.
snippet: David K. P. Li, an aristocratic banker in Hong Kong, is expected to be questioned about a possible insider-trading case involving shares of Dow Jones.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, May 9 — Like David Rockefeller in the United States and a succession of Rothschilds in Europe, David K. P. Li has long received the accolades that come to aristocratic bankers who combine wealth, political influence and public service.

headline.main: Prominent in Hong Kong and, Perhaps, in the Dow Jones Inquiry
headline.print_headline: Prominent in Hong Kong and, Perhaps, in the Dow Jones Inquiry

abstract: Many in Hong Kong were surprised to learn that a local aristocrat and business magnate, David K.P. Li, may come under scrutiny in relation to stock trading ahead of Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion for Dow Jones. But the investigation by American regulators into the possible leak of confidential information could have wider effects, potentially damaging the city’s attempts to shake its reputation for financial regulations that are weaker than the West’s, The New York Times reports. Hong Kong only made insider trading a criminal offense in 2003, and has not yet brought any prosecutions under the statute.
lead_paragraph: Many in Hong Kong were surprised to learn that a local aristocrat and business magnate, David K.P. Li, may come under scrutiny in relation to stock trading ahead of Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion for Dow Jones. But the investigation by American regulators into the possible leak of confidential information could have wider effects, potentially damaging the city’s attempts to shake its reputation for financial regulations that are weaker than the West’s, The New York Times reports. Hong Kong only made insider trading a criminal offense in 2003, and has not yet brought any prosecutions under the statute.

headline.main: Dow Jones Inquiry Could Be Awkward for Hong Kong

abstract: Rupert Murdoch, the chief executive of the News Corporation, on Wednesday defended his unsolicited offer for Dow Jones, which has run into opposition from the Bancroft family, the company’s controlling shareholders, and from Dow Jones employees.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch, the chief executive of the News Corporation, on Wednesday defended his unsolicited offer for Dow Jones, which has run into opposition from the Bancroft family, the company’s controlling shareholders, and from Dow Jones employees.

headline.main: From Murdoch, Sweet Words, Not a Sweetened Bid

abstract: The speed with which the Securities and Exchange Commission identified and took action against alleged insider trading in Dow Jones stock this week was “a phenomenal achievement,” Harvey Pitt, the S.E.C.’s former chairman, declared in an interview with The Wall Street Journal’s Law Blog. Mr. Pitt, who served from 2001 to 2003, said that “in the old days, it took a while to figure out who knew what, when and where. I would say enforcement is alive and well.”
lead_paragraph: The speed with which the Securities and Exchange Commission identified and took action against alleged insider trading in Dow Jones stock this week was “a phenomenal achievement,” Harvey Pitt, the S.E.C.’s former chairman, declared in an interview with The Wall Street Journal’s Law Blog. Mr. Pitt, who served from 2001 to 2003, said that “in the old days, it took a while to figure out who knew what, when and where. I would say enforcement is alive and well.”

headline.main: Harvey Pitt on Insider Trading, Then and Now
